# EVALUATION PROMPT (Sharper, more critical, human‑aligned v2)

You are a senior product design hiring manager evaluating portfolio websites based on visual craft only. Judge only what is visible in the provided page(s)/images. Do not infer quality from brands, content, or reputation.

## Evaluation Rules

1. Scoring posture (critical, calibrated, evidence‑first):
   - Default anchor is 3 (Average/Competent). Begin each dimension at 3 only when the work is readable and basically organized. Move up or down strictly on visible evidence.
   - Break test: before moving above 3, try to find at least 3 flaws (e.g., casing drift, crop cut‑offs, width drift). If you can, hold at 2–3.
   - Be skeptical of “tidy but generic.” Default‑ish type, boilerplate layouts, or lightly styled templates should be 2–3 unless you see clear bespoke tuning and micro‑craft.
   - Do not award 4–5 for “not broken” execution. Scores 4–5 require sustained refinement across multiple sections and/or a distinctive, coherent POV that improves clarity and cohesion.
   - Evidence‑limited views: When only a single hero or single section is visible, cap each dimension at 3 unless either the Minimalism Micro‑Craft Check or the Elevated Basics Check passes (see Rule 2). Never award 5 without multiple sections unless the visible view shows unmistakable master‑level micro‑craft.
   - Apply caps from red flags (Rules 7 and 9). If template scent is strong without counter‑evidence, cap Typography and Layout at 3. If sloppy image cues ≥3, cap Layout at 2 and consider Color 2 when mismatched whites/mats cause flicker. If both template_scent_high and sloppy_images are present, hold Layout at 2 max and be conservative elsewhere.

2. Two ways a single refined view can justify a 4 (stricter; verify each signal; any disqualifier below fails the check):
   - Minimalism Micro‑Craft Check (pass when ≥5 signals are present):
     - Tuned neutrals (off‑black/off‑white; borders/shadows with gentle hue shifts and controlled values).
     - Customized link styling (non‑default hue and underline thickness/offset; clear hover or convincingly implied consistency).
     - Measured typographic rhythm (predictable scale steps; stable baseline; no widows/orphans; intentional hyphenation and rags; consistent punctuation and casing).
     - Intentional spacing system (e.g., 4/8/12 multiples; even row rhythm; no accidental half‑gutter gaps).
     - Optical alignment corrections (icons aligned to x‑height/caps; bullets/dividers centered optically; numerals/symbols sit correctly).
     - Hierarchy achieved with minimal styles (tone/weight/spacing) yet unambiguous; label/meta styles repeat exactly.
     - Disciplined image/list presentation (matching aspect ratios, radii, mats, caption positions; screenshots readable; no emoji bullets or novelty icons used as structure).
     - Cohesive bespoke touches (editorial serif paired with care; caret/arrow icons aligned to cap height; button strokes matching surrounding type weight; no default blue).
   - Elevated Basics Check (for default‑leaning but carefully tuned designs; pass when ≥6 signals are present):
     - Comfortable measures (45–80ch body) and consistent 1.3–1.7 leading; display leading tighter but non‑colliding.
     - Consistent link treatment even if conservative; underline weight/offset intentional; states visible or plausibly consistent.
     - Neutrals feel considered (soft grey dividers, off‑black text); no harsh pure #000/#fff pairs; shadows/borders with subtle tints.
     - Repetition handled with discipline (long card/icon grids keep identical mats, radii, border weights, caption rhythm).
     - Clear text scale system repeated across sections; punctuation/quotes consistent; no random bolding to simulate hierarchy.
     - Accents are sparse and role‑clear; imagery carries color without clashing; mats/borders unify diverse screenshots.
     - No sloppy artifacts (no jaggies/compression; crops and radii match; consistent shadow/border logic; screenshots readable; device frames avoided or customized with readable content).
   - Disqualifiers for both checks (any one present fails the check and caps the dimension at 3 max; two or more disqualifiers should pull to 2):
     - Inconsistent casing across similar elements (e.g., hero sentence case, nav all‑caps, titles Title Case without logic).
     - Emoji or novelty icons used as bullets causing irregular indents/line heights.
     - Random tracking/over‑tracked all‑caps; monospace used for body or in CTAs without rationale; button stroke weight mismatched to adjacent type.
     - Oversized personal nameplate in the nav competing with hero/title, or billboard words used as filler/cropped letterforms.
     - Perceived container‑width drift (e.g., wide nav, narrow hero rag, wide body) without rationale; floaty outline CTA not tied to grid.
     - Unreadable screenshots or device frames with tiny UI; visible cut‑off crops.

3. Score each dimension on a 1–5 scale:
   - 1: Poor
   - 2: Below average
   - 3: Average (competent baseline)
   - 4: Strong (refined and intentional)
   - 5: Exceptional (rare, masterful, original, and controlled)

4. For each dimension, you MUST:
   - Provide a score (1–5).
   - Write a concise explanation citing at least 3 concrete visual observations (e.g., “even 56–64ch measure,” “underline offset aligns to x‑height,” “tile radii unified at 12px; borders 1px with subtle hue shift,” “status bars cut off,” “masonry gutters uneven; left column bottoms don’t align,” “center/left alignment alternates without grid reason”).
   - Call out at least one limitation, even for scores ≥4, to avoid uncritical praise.
   - If you apply a red flag, list at least two matching cues and state the cap you applied.
   - Rate your confidence (1–5). If evidence is partial (e.g., only a hero or one section), set confidence ≤3.

5. Avoid context bias:
   - Ignore brands, company names, and content substance.
   - Evaluate only visible visual execution and design craft.

6. Calibration and exemplars:
   - Use exemplar ratings as calibration anchors.
   - Apply the same standard across evaluations. Minimal, text‑forward pages can earn 4–5 when micro‑craft is clearly elevated (see Rule 2), especially when long, repeated grids show flawless rhythm/alignment.
   - “Considered variation” is allowed. Collage or gallery layouts can be strong when gutters, captions, and optical alignment repeat exactly. Penalize sloppy inconsistency, not deliberate variation.

7. Red flags (detect and list them explicitly when present):
   - template_scent_high
   - sloppy_images
   - process_soup
   - When you flag any red flag, cite at least two matching cues (Rule 9) in your explanations. Apply the related caps and be conservative with scores. Err on the side of flagging sloppy_images when ≥2 cues are visible, especially unreadable screenshots, mixed radii/mats, or cut‑off crops.

8. Innovation vs basic competence:
   - Do not award 4–5 for centered heroes, uniform grids, outline “VIEW PROJECT” buttons, device‑mock rows, or logo bands if they read boilerplate or default. “Looks fine” is a 3.
   - Reward originality only when it improves comprehension and is executed with control (alignment, rhythm, hierarchy, and color remain strong). A refined, cohesive visual system that harmonizes complex imagery can be exceptional even with minimal styling.

9. Quick template/sloppiness scan (use to inform red flags and to avoid overrating):
   - Template scent cues (3+ suggests template_scent_high; cap Typography/Layout at 3 unless strong counter‑evidence exists):
     - Copy‑paste tokens from UI kits: identical 12/16px radii everywhere; 24/24 paddings; Tailwind/Bootstrap default blues/purples; Inter/Roboto link blue with default underline/visited purple.
     - Stock hero patterns: “I’m [Name] …” or “Hi, I’m …” headline; down‑arrow “See projects”; oversized personal nameplate in nav competing with hero; billboard words (e.g., “OTHER PROJECTS”) that dominate sections.
     - Uncustomized modules: left text/right device hero; alternating light/dark bands; uniform two‑column rows with identical outline “VIEW” buttons; centered “CASE STUDIES” label above left‑aligned content; logo bands of mixed‑color client marks as filler; boilerplate footer; “Made with Framer/Webflow” badge.
     - Notion/Figma‑style blocks with unmodified toggles/dividers; generic device frames; cookie‑cutter badges/pills with identical shadows; random handwriting doodle beside default UI.
     - Unexplained switches between center/left alignment and inconsistent container widths mirroring theme defaults.
     - Background billboard words as filler; oversized CTA panels that break rhythm/value without reason.
     - Important: Do not flag solely for a centered hero + grid if bespoke tuning is evident (consistent mats, tuned neutrals, customized links, optical alignment). Require 3+ cues before flagging.
   - Sloppy execution cues (2+ suggests sloppy_images and should pull scores down; if 3+ are present, cap Layout at 2 and consider Color 2 when mats/whites flicker):
     - Inconsistent crops/aspect ratios; mixed or mismatched corner radii; aliasing/jaggies; compression or non‑retina blur; screenshots too zoomed out to read; status bars cut off; device mock content illegible; letterforms cropped by section edges.
     - Mixed device frames (phone/laptop/desktop) or real‑world device photos that dominate while diminishing readability; screenshots cut off or with thick, varying internal mats.
     - Shadow/border values fluctuate without logic; captions misaligned to tiles; stray 1–2px misalignments repeated; pixel wobble across grids; outline/button stroke weights that don’t match body text weight.
     - Irregular masonry gutters and inconsistent whitespace around tiles; full‑color social or client logos used as graphic tiles without harmonization; colored outlines around social icons.
   - Process soup cues:
     - Walls of sticky notes, personas, or unreadable timelines dominating above final visuals; deliverables with tiny text that cannot be evaluated; little or no polished product shots.

10. Execution checklists before scoring (aim to catch common misses and reduce leniency):

   - Typography:
     - Casing and consistency: verify sentence vs Title Case rules; nav vs headings vs labels; mismatches are a deduction (repeated across sections pulls to 2).
     - Nameplate sizing: personal name/logotype in nav should not visually dominate hero/title; oversized nameplate is a deduction (repeated with tight tracking pulls Typography to 2).
     - Bullets and lists: check indent alignment and line‑height; over‑indented bullets or emoji bullets reduce score. Verify list markers align optically with text blocks.
     - Tracking/weight: penalize over‑tracked all‑caps; “everything bold”; random word‑level bolding to fake hierarchy.
     - Link treatment: hue, underline thickness/offset, visited/hover cues; penalize default blue with default underline.
     - Pairing logic: avoid editorial/display or monospace for body; detect mixed fonts in buttons vs body; ensure button stroke weights match type weight.
     - Measure/leading: confirm body 45–80ch; leading 1.3–1.7; heroes >~90–100ch are too long; long center‑aligned blocks with heavy weight are a deduction.

   - Layout & Composition:
     - Grid/gutter consistency; spacing system in 4/8/12 multiples. Look for width drift: wide nav → narrow hero → wide body (or perceived drift from ragged hero text). Penalize both real and perceived mismatches that read as different container widths.
     - Alignment discipline: avoid unjustified center/left switches; detect edge/rag drift; note floaty outline CTAs; ensure captions and buttons align to the grid; align bottoms in paired tiles.
     - Image framing: mats, border weights, corner radii; detect generic device mocks and unreadable screenshots; check for cut‑off crops and letterforms cropped by panels.
     - Repetition: identical caption positions and offsets; consistent tile aspect ratios; beware irregular masonry or collage with flickering whitespace; penalize mixed device frames alongside UI tiles when they break rhythm.

   - Color:
     - Tuned neutrals vs harsh #000/#fff; accent role clarity and consistency; link/CTA state logic.
     - Unification tactics: mats/borders/shadow tints that harmonize diverse imagery; avoid bright footers or tiles that jump in value and break the system.
     - Penalize noisy additions: full‑color social/client logos in minimal shells; colored outlines around icons/logos; pastel mats that fail to tame saturated UI; billboard color panels that spike value without clear purpose.
     - Evaluate value control across tiles; reward when a neutral shell elegantly contains highly varied artwork without value flicker.

## Output Format

Return only valid JSON matching this exact structure:
```json
{
  "candidate_id": "X",
  "scores": {
    "typography": {
      "score": 1-5,
      "explanation": "detailed reasoning with specific evidence",
      "confidence": 1-5
    },
    "layout_composition": {
      "score": 1-5,
      "explanation": "detailed reasoning with specific evidence",
      "confidence": 1-5
    },
    "color": {
      "score": 1-5,
      "explanation": "detailed reasoning with specific evidence",
      "confidence": 1-5
    }
  },
  "red_flags": ["list any that apply"],
  "overall_weighted_score": calculated_number,
  "overall_confidence": calculated_number
}
```

## Scoring Calculation
- base_score = (typography × 0.35) + (layout_composition × 0.35) + (color × 0.30)
- penalty = sum of red flag penalties:
  - template_scent_high: 0.8 points
  - sloppy_images: 0.7 points
  - process_soup: 0.3 points
- overall_weighted_score = base_score - penalty
- overall_confidence = average of individual dimension confidences

---

## RUBRIC

Use the full 1–5 range. The “Score 3” rows define the competent baseline. Default to 3 when evidence is mixed, default‑ish, or generic. Use 4–5 only when criteria are clearly met across multiple sections, or when a single view passes Rule 2. Round down when sloppy cues or template scent appear.

## Typography (Weight: 35%)

Examine closely (cite specifics):
- Typeface quality (pro‑grade vs overused free), appropriateness, and pairing logic.
- Hierarchy via scale ratios, weight, spacing, tone—not only bolding.
- Readability: body 45–80ch; line‑height 1.3–1.7; display tighter leading without collisions.
- Consistency: heading levels, list styles, link treatment (underline thickness/offset), baseline rhythm, quote punctuation and apostrophes, superscripts/subscripts alignment, casing/capitalization patterns.
- Micro‑craft: optical kerning for all‑caps; punctuation spacing; small‑caps quality; number alignment; hyphenation/rag control.

Score 5: Exceptional
- Minimal style set yields rich, unmistakable hierarchy with impeccable rhythm across sections.
- Pairing (or single family) shows mastery; details tuned (optical alignment, kerning, consistent cap/ascender spacing; intentional hyphenation; no widows/orphans; bullets align; lists indent cleanly).
- Distinct typographic voice that feels bespoke yet highly readable. Link/label systems are rigorously consistent, including states and edge cases.
- Accept that masterful long grids and text‑forward pages can earn 5 even without visible link states if every other micro‑detail is flawless across many sections.

Score 4: Strong
- Clear hierarchy with restrained, consistent styles; comfortable measures and leading across sections.
- Evident scale system across multiple elements; link styling is customized and consistent or convincingly intentional even when conservative.
- “Elevated basics” allowed: a common system sans/serif can earn 4 if rhythm, measures, punctuation, casing, and link treatment are disciplined and repeat.
- Minor issues only (e.g., a slightly hot link hue, one tight display line, a narrow rag).

Score 3: Competent baseline
- Readable with adequate hierarchy and a limited style set; may feel generic.
- Choices can be default‑ish (system sans + near‑default link blue) but aren’t broken.
- Some inconsistencies: heading levels too close; uneven bullet spacing/indentation; occasional baseline drift; a widow/orphan; inconsistent smart quotes; slight casing mismatch limited to one area.

Score 2: Below average
- Multiple issues that reduce polish and clarity:
  - Inconsistent capitalization/casing across similar elements or sentences; “everything bold”; random word‑level bolding.
  - Emoji used as bullets creating irregular indents/line height; over‑indented lists; tall/heavy vertical dividers overpowering labels.
  - Random tracking or overuse of all‑caps; display/editorial or monospace used for body; mixed font in CTAs/buttons vs body.
  - Link styling clearly default with thick default underline; mixed link treatments; no visible or implied state logic.
  - Repeated widows/orphans, sloppy rags, unstable baselines across sections.
  - Oversized personal nameplate/logotype competing with the main title; billboard words as typographic decor.
- Voice reads generic or junior despite basic legibility.

Score 1: Poor
- Flat or confusing hierarchy; style proliferation; unreadable measures (very long/very tight lines, e.g., hero ~90–100ch); collisions/overlaps; inconsistent quotes/apostrophes and punctuation; broken lists/labels throughout.

Negative indicators that should pull to 2 (or 1 when frequent):
- Default link blue with default underline; pervasive casing inconsistency; emoji bullets; visible reflow collisions; mismatched button font/outline; button stroke weights that don’t match text; oversized personal nameplate in nav competing with hero.

Refined minimal vs generic minimal:
- Refined: tuned neutrals; customized underline weight/offset; disciplined scale steps; stable baselines; optical alignment of icons/marks; consistent micro‑labels and dates; intentional hyphenation; bullets align with text blocks; casing consistently applied.
- Generic: default link blue and underline; uneven paragraph spacing; arbitrary size jumps; mixed alignment without rationale; unmodified Notion export vibes; over‑tracked all‑caps; nav/hero sizing competition.

## Layout & Composition (Weight: 35%)

Examine:
- Grid usage: columns, gutters, container widths; spacing system (multiples of 4/8/12).
- Structural clarity: section breaks, scan patterns, focal points, navigation affordances.
- Image presentation: consistent crops, device‑frame consistency or bespoke mats; matching radii/border weights/shadows; readable screenshots.
- Innovation with control: novel structures that aid comprehension; restraint that still shows a point of view.
- Breadth of evidence: multiple sections vs single hero; consistency across the page and visible breakpoints.

Score 5: Exceptional
- Masterful structure with a clear POV that elevates clarity (inventive yet disciplined layouts; precise orchestration across columns/sections).
- Immaculate rhythm and alignment across breakpoints; optical fixes for asymmetric content; complex, long grids remain perfectly in sync.
- Assets are harmonized (radii, borders, shadows, captions) with flawless consistency across diverse content. Minimal pages with large, repeated galleries can earn 5 when mats/captions/gutters are exact and screenshots are readable.

Score 4: Strong
- Consistent grid and spacing; clear section hierarchy; strong alignment across sections.
- Image/asset handling is deliberate and cohesive; cards/tiles feel unified and intentional.
- Long repeated grids are disciplined (identical mats, radii, caption positions, gutter rhythm).
- Minor roughness allowed (one floaty element, a narrow gutter anomaly, or a single misaligned caption corrected elsewhere).
- Collage may earn 4 when variation is intentional and gutters, baselines, and caption styles repeat exactly, with no cut‑offs.

Score 3: Competent baseline
- Basic grid present and mostly consistent; sections readable with adequate spacing.
- Common patterns (single column, centered hero, simple card grid, left‑text/right‑image hero) executed decently but without sophistication or a clear POV.
- Some inconsistencies in gutters, container widths, vertical rhythm, or image placement; default device frames with light tuning.

Score 2: Below average
- Noticeable structural problems:
  - Container width drift across sections or perceived drift (e.g., wide nav → narrower hero rag → wide body) with no rationale.
  - Unexplained switches between center and left alignment; awkward rags; floaty CTAs not tied to a grid.
  - Masonry/collage tiles with inconsistent whitespace; irregular bottoms/tops; crops cut off; letterforms cropped by section edges.
  - Reliance on generic device mocks where screenshots are small/unreadable; mixed tile aspect ratios produce rhythm flicker; inconsistent internal mats; mixed device photos alongside UI mocks that break cohesion.
  - Oversized headings/labels overpower content; misaligned buttons/captions; logo bands as filler that disrupt rhythm.
- Layout reads like an uncustomized template or a pile of modules.

Score 1: Poor
- Random placement; competing focal points; inconsistent container widths and gutters; severe readability issues.
- Haphazard screenshot handling; inconsistent radii/shadows; elements hugging edges or overflowing at visible breakpoints.

Common deductions and caps:
- Evidence limited to a single hero or short view: cap at 3 unless Rule 2 passes.
- “Clean but generic”: centered hero + simple grid with soft shadows/rounded corners and no POV—do not exceed 3 without visible refinement (precise rhythm, tuned mats, optical alignment).
- Template modules repeated with little customization: cap at 3 and consider template_scent_high.
- If sloppy_images cues ≥3 (cut‑offs, unreadable mocks, mixed radii/crops), cap Layout at 2 and pull Color down when grid flicker is caused by mismatched whites/mats.

## Color (Weight: 30%)

Examine:
- Palette quality: harmony, hue/value control, consistency across sections.
- Neutrals: tuned greys/blacks; hue‑shifted borders and shadows; subtle overlays.
- Accent strategy: scarcity and consistency; link/CTA states; role clarity.
- Integration with imagery: do mats/borders/shadow tints unify diverse screenshots/tiles? Is value step‑down controlled across rows/sections?

Score 5: Exceptional
- Sophisticated palette with precise value control; accents sparse yet highly effective.
- Neutrals and shadows are tuned; borders/overlays have intentional tints; color choices unify varied content effortlessly, including complex artwork.
- Color expresses identity without noise, consistently across sections and states. Neutral shells that elegantly contain very varied tiles can earn 5 when value control remains calm.

Score 4: Strong
- Harmonious palette with controlled accents; link/CTA system clearly defined or convincingly implied by consistent usage.
- Neutrals intentionally tuned (off‑black/off‑white) supporting readability and hierarchy; gradients/illustrations sit comfortably within the system.
- “Elevated basics” acceptable: conservative blue accent can qualify for 4 when mats, borders, and greys are tuned and unify colorful content.
- Minor issues only (one accent slightly hot; a single mismatched gradient; a footer a bit heavy but close; limited state evidence).

Score 3: Competent baseline
- Serviceable palette; minimal shell with a single accent or defaultish link blue used acceptably.
- When colorful tiles carry most color, the chrome does not clash but lacks unifying tactics (e.g., inconsistent mats/shadows/border tints) that would lift it to 4.
- States may be missing but implied by stable patterns.

Score 2: Below average
- Too many hues or values without a throughline; loud tiles overpower a claimed single‑accent scheme.
- Flat untuned greys; harsh #000/#fff pairs; default bright link blue; inconsistent state colors.
- Mixed tile backgrounds and mismatched whites causing grid flicker; full‑color social/client logos add noise; colored outlines around low‑importance elements.
- Pastel mats attempted but overwhelmed by saturated foreground content; billboard color panels that spike value without role clarity.

Score 1: Poor
- Clashing gradients; muddy overlays; illegible contrast; chaotic color with no role clarity.

Negative indicators that should pull to 2:
- Pure #000/#fff with harsh 0,0,255‑like blue; mismatched tile backgrounds; muddy overlays; random hover colors; inconsistent visited link behavior; pastel mats that fail to unify against saturated UIs; social logo rows/add‑on badges pulling attention; aggressive value jumps (e.g., cobalt or teal panels shocking against a pale shell).

Tuned vs default color in minimal pages:
- Tuned: slightly desaturated or hue‑shifted blue; consistent underline thickness/offset; hover/visited handled or implied by pattern; off‑black/off‑white neutrals; very light, even dividers; unified mats/shadows around images.
- Default: pure black/white; harsh default blues; generic heavy shadows; inconsistent border tints; tiles with different corner radii or shadow directions; full‑color logos/emoji adding noise.

## Red Flags

Flag these when clearly present and reflect them in explanations. Add a flag only when you can name at least two matching cues; otherwise omit and reduce confidence.

- template_scent_high:
  - Obvious boilerplate patterns with minimal customization: centered “I’m [Name]” hero; left text/right device hero; generic down arrow; uniform 2‑column rows with outline “VIEW PROJECT” buttons; billboard background words; stock “About” block; logo bands as filler; boilerplate footer; default link styles; visible “Made with …” badge.
  - Tokens mirroring popular UI kits without page‑level decisions: identical 12/16px radii everywhere; 24/24 paddings; Tailwind/Bootstrap default blues; identical card shadows; Inter/Roboto with untouched link defaults; Notion‑style layouts with unmodified toggles/dividers; emoji bullets as structure; oversized personal nameplate in nav.
  - Repeated canned sections with identical structure, no bespoke decisions, no tuning of mats/shadows/links; unexplained alternating center/left alignment and container widths that follow theme defaults.

- sloppy_images:
  - Inconsistent crops/aspect ratios; mixed/mismatched corner radii; aliasing/jaggies; compression artifacts; non‑retina blur; screenshots cut off or too zoomed out to read; tiny UI inside device frames; letterforms cropped by panel edges.
  - Generic device frames without customization; unreadable screenshot content; inconsistent mats/shadows/border weights; white‑balance mismatch across tiles; irregular masonry gutters and inconsistent whitespace around tiles.
  - Misaligned captions/labels; inconsistent drop‑shadow directions; pixel wobble across a grid; outline/button strokes not matching text weight; full‑color social/client logos used as graphic tiles without harmonization; colored outlines on social icons.

- process_soup:
  - Long timelines/diagrams overwhelming final visuals; walls of sticky‑note photos overshadowing product.
  - Persona/journey maps with unreadable small text; very little outcome imagery; excessive wireframes with no polished result.

Note: If uncertain, omit the flag and reduce confidence instead. If you do flag, list the cues you observed in your explanations.

---

## EXEMPLAR CALIBRATION

Use these exemplars to calibrate. Note how minimal pages can score 4–5 when micro‑craft is obvious, and how template scent or sloppy images must pull scores down. Apply the rubric consistently.

Exemplar 1 (Score: 4.0)
Portfolio category: Minimal, text‑forward
Why 4 (not 3): Type system is disciplined with tuned neutrals; customized link treatment; even 56–64ch measures; stable baselines. Layout is restrained but confident with consistent rhythm across long sections. Color is conservative yet tuned; imagery is harmonized with light mats. Minor limitation: limited evidence of interactive states.

Exemplar 2 (Score: 2.0–2.4)
Portfolio category: Template‑leaning with sloppy imagery
Why ~2.2 (not 3): Centered “I’m [Name]” hero; default link blue with default underline; outline “VIEW PROJECT” buttons in identical two‑column rows; billboard “OTHER PROJECTS” word dominating and cropping letterforms (template_scent_high flagged). Mixed radii and unreadable device screenshots; inconsistent masonry whitespace; several crops cut off; full‑color social logos with colored outlines at the footer (sloppy_images flagged). Layout capped at 2 due to ≥3 sloppy cues; Typography at 2 for casing inconsistencies and over‑tracked all‑caps; Color at 2 for hue/value flicker from mismatched tiles and logo noise

typography.explanation: Clear, restrained type system. 1) Hero copy uses a comfortable measure (~55–65ch) with steady 1.4–1.5 leading; no widows or orphans visible. 2) Consistent sans serif voice across sections; small labels like “Thoughts” and “Latest Projects” reuse the same size/weight pattern. 3) Micro‑CTAs (e.g., pill “Previous Work” and small arrow links on cards) align well to the x‑height, and spacing around them is even. 4) Off‑black body text improves readability over pure black. Limitation: link styling/states are not demonstrated (no underline/hover evidence), and center‑aligned section labels depart slightly from the otherwise left‑aligned rhythm.

layout_composition.explanation: Overall grid is clean and spacious. 1) The top row of three project tiles share identical aspect ratios, corner radii, and even gutters, indicating a controlled grid. 2) The white 'About' card sits on the same column width and uses a consistent shadow/border logic as other tiles. 3) The horizontal 'Latest Projects' rail keeps uniform tile widths and consistent spacing. Limitations: noticeable alignment switches (left‑aligned hero, centered 'About' card and section labels, then left‑aligned footer block) reduce cohesion; a small black dot near the top right reads as a floaty decorative element not tied to the grid; varied image densities in the project rail slightly disturb vertical rhythm.

color.explanation: Neutrals and accents feel intentional. 1) Off‑white background with near‑black text keeps contrast comfortable; shadows are soft grey rather than harsh black. 2) The three hero tiles use saturated brand panels (purple/blue/orange) but remain contained by matching mats/radii, so the shell stays calm. 3) Black pill buttons and small arrows provide a clear, consistent accent. Limitation: the 'Latest Projects' rail mixes photos, UI, and product shots with varied value/saturation, causing mild flicker despite consistent containers.

typography.explanation: Readable, minimal type with a small sans-serif nameplate in the top-left; nav items (Work, About) show consistent weight contrast to indicate the active page; no default blue underlines or noisy link styling; the nameplate does not overpower the page. Rags are clean and spacing around the nav is even. Limitations: very little text shown beyond the nav, no visible link/hover states, and no demonstrable scale system or paragraph rhythm. Evidence limited to a single view, so capped at 3 per rule.

layout_composition.explanation: Crisp 2×2 project grid with equal horizontal and vertical gutters; comfortable outer margins and strong top whitespace; nav aligns cleanly with the left edge of the grid; image crops appear intentional and high-resolution. Minor roughness: tile backgrounds vary (white/grey/pink/black device shot) which creates value flicker; the upper-left tile’s large internal whitespace vs other tiles introduces slight balance inconsistency. Single-screen evidence—no long-page rhythm or multi-section consistency to verify—so capped at 3.

color.explanation: Neutral white shell keeps focus on work; light grey mat behind one tile and a soft pink tile provide gentle variation; black nav text and subtle inactive state (About) are controlled. However, brand artwork introduces disparate saturated hues (red/blue/black/pink) without a visible unifying accent system, causing small value jumps between tiles (e.g., black device tile vs pale backgrounds). No visible state system for links or buttons. Evidence limited to one section, so baseline score.

typography.explanation: Readable, neutral sans with simple hierarchy. Observations: 1) Centered hero with comfortable leading and a short supporting blurb; 2) Links use a green color with default-looking underline thickness/offset (no visible hover/state system); 3) Navigation uses all‑caps with an outlined 'WORK' pill, while hero is sentence case—mixed casing styles without a clear rule; 4) Footer link list appears tight with small leading and minimal differentiation between items. Voice feels generic and does not show bespoke tuning or micro‑craft. Limitation: no evidence of a disciplined scale system or refined link styling across sections.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is clean and conventional. Observations: 1) 3×3 project grid has equal square tiles and consistent gutters; 2) Hero block centered above the grid with predictable spacing; 3) Footer switches to a full‑width light grey band with two simple columns and social icons on the right. Limitations: template‑like modules (centered hero + uniform grid + basic footer), abrupt value shift into the grey footer, and limited evidence of complex layout decisions or multi‑section rhythm.

color.explanation: Neutral shell with dark grey text is serviceable; a single green accent for links. Observations: 1) Highly saturated full‑bleed thumbnails across many hues create visual flicker without mats to harmonize; 2) The green link accent is isolated (no clear system for buttons/states) and competes slightly with the multicolored tiles; 3) Footer grey band increases contrast abruptly relative to the white body. Limitation: lacks unifying tactics (e.g., consistent mats/borders or tuned shadows) to manage diverse artwork.

typography.explanation: Clear, confident hierarchy: oversized display stack ('Designer. Manager…') contrasted with small meta and consistent section labels. Links are customized (non‑default color, arrow suffix 'Read more →' and 'Follow me on Twitter →') and repeat consistently. Body excerpts show comfortable measure/leading and stable rags across the article grid. Section watermarks ('Selected Projects', 'Latest Articles') are handled as low‑contrast display without crowding nearby text. Minor issues: billboard‑scale hero verges on decorative; casing varies between Title Case for project titles and sentence case elsewhere; article link text appears slightly light versus background, reducing emphasis.

layout_composition.explanation: Strong grid discipline: hero uses a clean two‑column composition with the portrait aligned to the content block; section transitions marked by a consistent light‑gray band and oversized watermark type; gutters appear even across the project tiles and article cards. Project tiles share consistent mats, radii, label positions ('01/02/03'), and shadow treatment, creating a unified row; article list forms a steady three‑column rhythm with matching caption offsets and 'Read more' placement. Minor roughness: second project row mixes device types so screenshot readability varies; the 'View All' pill in both sections feels slightly floaty relative to the grid; the large watermark words underlap content which can compete with hierarchy on smaller viewports.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals: off‑white background with soft gray section banding; off‑black text prevents harsh contrast. Accents are restrained—subtle gray pills, monochrome link text with arrows—and colorful imagery (portrait and app UIs) is contained by dark mats so the page stays calm. Shadows are soft and consistent, helping unify diverse device imagery. Minor issues: the watermark headings are a bright white that spikes value against the gray band; a few device tiles carry strong brand colors that momentarily outshine the otherwise quiet chrome.

typography.explanation: Refined, minimal type system with clear hierarchy. Body copy sits at a comfortable ~58–64ch measure with ~1.45–1.6 leading; meta line ('Updated July 8, 2024') uses a lighter grey and smaller size for a consistent scale step. Links are customized with a subtle blue and an external‑link glyph aligned to the cap height/x‑height, indicating bespoke link styling. Rags are tidy with no widows/orphans visible; punctuation and casing appear consistent. Limitation: link blue feels a touch default and there’s no visible state treatment or longer multi‑section proof of rhythm.

layout_composition.explanation: Single‑column composition is disciplined and balanced. The timeline list shows a clear 3‑column structure: left‑aligned year, centered title block, right‑aligned day/month, with identical row heights and subtle 1px dividers—good spacing discipline (reads like 8/16 multiples). The central column width remains consistent; ample negative space around the content avoids width drift. External‑link icons and inline elements sit on a stable baseline without visible misalignments. Limitation: evidence is a single view—no demonstration of more complex sections or responsive variations.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals: off‑white background, off‑black body text, and soft grey for meta text and dividers create calm value control. Blue links provide a single accent used consistently; tiny external‑link icons match the tone and don’t spike contrast. The palette keeps varied content (text rows) cohesive without flicker. Limitation: the blue leans slightly default and there’s limited evidence of state colors or more complex color integration.

typography.explanation: Clean, readable sans set with clear hierarchy: bold name + lighter handle/tagline; sentence case used consistently across bubbles; comfortable line height inside chat bubbles keeps short measures readable. Link/meta pills under the name show a consistent small-label style with icons. However, the typographic voice is generic (system/Inter-like), link styling is not clearly differentiated from body text in bubbles, and there’s limited long-form text to verify rhythm, scale steps, or baseline discipline.

layout_composition.explanation: Cohesive conversational single-column layout with alternating left/right chat bubbles that align to a stable central column; spacing between bubbles appears to follow even increments, creating steady vertical rhythm. Project cards are grouped inside rounded containers with matching radii and consistent internal mats; two-up and single-card sections keep identical guttering. The social icon row uses equal-size rounded squares aligned to the same grid, maintaining balance. Limitation: screenshots inside cards are small/unreadable at this zoom, and the chat pattern, while distinctive, may slightly reduce scannability for quick project comparison.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals with a soft off-white/blue radial background; controlled grey bubbles contrasted with a single blue accent for response bubbles and the closing CTA, producing a clear conversational hierarchy. Shadows and highlights on bubbles/cards are subtle and hue-tinted, avoiding harsh #000/#fff contrast. Colorful project thumbs are well-contained by neutral mats. Minor roughness: brand-colored social icons introduce a bit of hue noise, and the blue gradient in some bubbles runs slightly hot compared to the otherwise calm palette.

typography.explanation: Readable serif body with comfortable ~55–65ch measure and generous 1.4–1.6 leading. Links appear in a bright defaultish blue with a standard underline weight/offset, suggesting little customization. Bullet points are typed as "•" characters, creating irregular indents and line-height wobble. Mixed pairing (serif body vs sans on buttons/nav) without clearly defined roles. Button copy like "Let's go ( password )" uses spaced parentheses and inconsistent casing, reducing polish. Limitation: no visible state system (hover/visited) and little evidence across multiple pages.

layout_composition.explanation: Simple two-column structure with ample whitespace and consistent horizontal dividers between sections. Headshot circle floats on the right and doesn’t anchor to the grid top/baseline, leaving a pocket of dead space. Right-side callout cards feel narrow and sit slightly detached from the left text block rhythm; vertical alignment between paragraph bottoms and card tops is not tuned. Bottom "Let’s connect" switches to centered social icons, breaking the left/right grid logic. Small logos inside the education block interrupt the text flow. Limitation: only one page view—no demonstration of responsiveness or longer grids.

color.explanation: Single accent family in blue is used consistently across links, CTAs, and callout cards. However, multiple blue values (light blue card, bright azure link, dark navy button) read as uncoordinated rather than a controlled scale. Neutrals appear as pure white background with near‑black/black text—serviceable but not tuned. Full‑color school/mascot marks introduce extra hues that add noise against the otherwise minimal palette. Limitation: no clear state color logic shown for interactions.

typography.explanation: Refined minimal type system with clear hierarchy. Body copy sits at a comfortable ~60–65ch measure with ~1.5 leading and clean rags; no widows visible. Section labels in the left rail (“About”, “Notes”, “Posts”, etc.) repeat with the same size/weight and spacing, giving a consistent meta style. Dates form a stable secondary column (“Fri, 28 Mar”, “2025 07”) that aligns neatly and uses lighter tone for hierarchy. Links are customized (black text with arrow suffix like “View all posts →”, not default blue) and appear consistently. Limitation: link affordance relies on subtle styling (no underline/state visible), and the line “Selected work. Let’s build something together” mixes a plain sentence with a linked one which could read ambiguous.

layout_composition.explanation: Clear three‑column structure: left rail for section labels, middle content column, wide right margin; alignment remains consistent across sections. Even vertical rhythm—identical spacing between About, Notes, Posts, Photos, and Contact; CTAs like “View all … →” align to the content column. Image handling is disciplined: a large, edge‑aligned hero image matches the content width; the Photos row uses four tiles with matching aspect ratio and equal gutters. Contact section forms a tidy two‑column table with uniform row spacing. Limitation: the large hero image’s height slightly outweighs the surrounding text, and only one viewport is visible so responsive discipline can’t be verified.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals: off‑white background with off‑black/soft gray text create calm contrast without harsh #000/#fff. Accent strategy is restrained—links remain neutral with arrow cues; no default blue. Diverse photo hues (warm stage image; cooler photo thumbnails) are contained by the minimal chrome, avoiding value flicker. Limitation: a defined accent color/state system isn’t evident (no hover/visited), and images lack mats/borders, which could challenge harmony if more saturated artwork appears.

typography.explanation: Large display italic serif sets a distinctive voice; left‑rag paragraph has a comfortable measure (~60–70ch) and even leading; links styled in saturated blue with an underline distinct from default. Years are set as superscripts next to company names, showing deliberate baseline control. Vertical side nav uses a light sans, pairing cleanly with the serif. Limitations: only a single hero is visible so system consistency and states can’t be judged; the long all‑italic paragraph reads a bit heavy for scannability; superscripts appear tight to preceding words, risking crowding.

layout_composition.explanation: Single‑column hero positioned with generous margins and ample negative space; text block anchored left with clear breathing room; rotated right‑edge nav (Work | Play | Contact) provides a secondary axis without clashing. Alignment feels steady and there’s no container width drift visible. Limitations: evidence is limited to one section; no card/grid rhythm to assess; the vertical nav floats somewhat independently from the main block with no visible grid tie‑back.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals: soft grey background and charcoal text avoid harsh #000/#fff; a single bright cobalt accent is used for links; contrast is strong and the palette is restrained. The accent creates a clear focal point on the name and employer links. Limitations: the cobalt runs slightly hotter than the otherwise muted shell; no additional sections or state treatments shown to evaluate palette cohesion across components.

typography.explanation: Intro paragraph runs at a comfortable ~60–70ch with ~1.5 leading; clean left rag with no obvious widows. Section labels (WORK— / PROJECTS—) are consistently styled in small/upper caps with an em‑dash and hairline rule, repeated exactly across sections. Captions follow a disciplined taxonomy: title + year line, then a lighter meta/description line with consistent punctuation. Overall voice is restrained and readable. Limitation: link styling/states aren’t visible, and the small caption size skirts the lower bound of readability; mixed casing (all‑caps project names vs sentence‑case body) introduces a slight tonal mismatch.

layout_composition.explanation: Clear grid: three even columns for the Work row with equal gutters; below, a denser multi‑column Projects grid with consistent tile widths and uniform spacing between image and caption. Captions are flush-left to tile edges and section spacing is even, producing a steady vertical rhythm. Footer micro‑row (email/links + updated date) sits neatly within the same container width. Limitations: imagery is presented raw without mats, causing value flicker (e.g., bright iPad photo between darker UI tiles); a "WIP" placeholder tile breaks polish; varying caption lengths create uneven row bottoms. Overall, solid but conventional thumbnail-grid structure without a distinct POV.

color.explanation: Neutral shell (soft white background, off‑black text) keeps focus on content; color is mostly carried by project art. No harsh default blues or clashing accents are visible. However, there’s limited unification: absence of mats/borders/shadow tints means bright items (white iPad photo) sit next to very dark code screenshots, creating local value spikes. No clear accent/link color system is evident.

typography.explanation: Readable, bold sans system with clear hierarchy (large display H1s, medium section titles, small body). Links are consistently blue with an arrow (e.g., 'Get in touch →', 'Framer' inline), and sentence case is used across headings. Measures look comfortable in the body/overview section (~60–70ch) with adequate leading. Limitations: the electric blue link color feels defaulty and lacks visible state/underline differentiation; the hero uses very heavy weight over a long multi‑line measure which feels a bit shouty; no evidence of nuanced micro‑craft (underline offset, tuned punctuation spacing, or refined small‑label styles).

layout_composition.explanation: Overall structure is clear: hero → featured project with wide screenshot and two‑column copy → resume overview → logo row → full‑bleed gradient CTA → promo block. Container widths feel consistent and spacing generous; the large UI screenshot sits on an even mat with a controlled shadow. Limitations: multiple decorative floating elements (3D arrow blobs and 'Krijn' chat‑pill stickers) sit off‑grid and read as floaty, weakening compositional discipline; the full‑bleed gradient band breaks the calm rhythm of the neutral sections and creates a sharp visual jump; the logo row and subsequent sections switch background values, introducing mild width/value drift in perception.

color.explanation: Neutral shell (off‑white, near‑black text) with a single bright blue accent used for links and emphasis is coherent. The logo strip uses monochrome marks on a light grey band, keeping noise low. The gradient CTA (orange→pink with circular glow) is executed smoothly. Limitations: the high‑chroma gradient section spikes value/saturation relative to the rest of the page, pulling focus disproportionately; the electric blue accent leans default and slightly clashes with the warm gradient; additional 3D stickers introduce extra hues not clearly integrated into the palette.

typography.explanation: Readable single‑column copy with comfortable measure (~60–70ch) and even leading (~1.45). Section labels (“Icons”, “Software”, “Work”) repeat a consistent style; icon captions pair a blue title with a light‑grey year in a predictable micro‑label pattern. Rags are clean with no obvious widows. However, the typographic voice is generic system/Inter‑like sans; link styling reads defaultish cobalt blue with no visible underline tuning or state cues; and some captions wrap to two lines creating minor rhythm inconsistency. Headings are small relative to body, reducing hierarchy punch.

layout_composition.explanation: Disciplined two‑column gallery: all tiles are square with matching corner radii and consistent internal mats; gutters are even across the long scroll; captions sit below tiles with the same offset throughout. The light card shells and repeated caption pattern harmonize very diverse artwork. Section breaks (“Icons” → “Software” → lists) keep a steady vertical rhythm and a single container width—no width drift or unjustified alignment switches. Minor roughness: occasional two‑line titles under tiles produce uneven row bottoms; intro copy feels slightly tight to the following grid.

color.explanation: Neutral shell (off‑white page, very light grey card mats) effectively contains saturated icon colors; shadows are soft and low‑chroma, avoiding value spikes. Accent strategy is restrained—links use a single blue; meta years in cool grey keep hierarchy clear. Despite the highly varied icon palettes, the consistent white/grey mats maintain harmony. Limitation: the blue accent reads a bit bright/default and states aren’t evident; occasional vivid icons momentarily spike value but are largely tamed by the mats.

typography.explanation: Readable sans-serif system with clear hierarchy: bold display headline, smaller meta labels above project titles, and body copy set to a comfortable ~60–70ch measure. Headline/subhead leading is adequate and not colliding. Meta labels (UX/UI, etc.) are consistently styled and spaced. Issues holding it at 3: inconsistent capitalization in project titles (e.g., “Data Management infrastructure,” “Text to Speech mobile app”), very generic type voice with little customization, and link/button styling feels defaultish (small outline 'Read More' with no visible state nuance). About text block gets dense with minimal paragraph rhythm.

layout_composition.explanation: Standard two‑column hero (left text, right portrait) with generous margins; clear sectioning and consistent gutters. Project sections repeat a predictable pattern; screenshots are centered in their lanes with even outer whitespace; the dark/light bands provide scannable breaks. Limitations: strong template pattern (alternating light/dark rows with identical outline CTAs), device/browser frames make the UI quite small and reduce focus, and value-heavy dark panels create abrupt vertical rhythm shifts. The metrics row feels sparse with large dead space, and the hero’s faint background word adds mild visual noise.

color.explanation: Conservative palette of white/near‑black with a teal accent applied to labels, rules, and buttons; accent use is consistent. Portrait and UI sit cleanly on the neutral shell. Limitations: dark sections read close to pure black, causing harsh jumps against the white sections; teal accent runs a bit hot relative to the neutrals; alternating black/white bands introduce noticeable value flicker rather than unifying diverse imagery.

typography.explanation: Readable sans system with clear hierarchy: a large left‑aligned hero with tight-but-non‑colliding leading; body text blocks sit around a comfortable ~60–70ch; section headings ('Experience', 'Education', 'Toolbox', 'More') repeat consistently and sub‑roles are distinguished by weight. Bullet lists under roles show consistent indent and marker alignment. Limitations: footer email shows default bright-blue, underlined link treatment that feels uncustomized and inconsistent with the rest; dark section appears to use pure white on near‑pure black which reads harsh; some list line-height on the dark section looks a touch tight for long bullets.

layout_composition.explanation: Clear structure with distinct section bands: white hero, full‑bleed dark 'Experience/Education', then light grey 'Toolbox/More'. Two‑column grid in the dark section (left label column, right content) maintains alignment and spacing; generous margins and consistent guttering improve scan. The hero balances a large headline on the left with a soft gradient accent on the right, creating a simple focal split. Limitations: overall layout is conventional with minimal POV; the right‑side gradient blob feels decorative and not tied to the grid; vertical rhythm between the dark band and the following light section has a slightly larger gap than elsewhere.

color.explanation: Conservative palette: white and light greys for content sections, a single dark band for emphasis, and a soft multicolor blur as a hero accent. Value control is mostly steady across sections and icons stay neutral. Limitations: the dark band appears near pure #000 with pure white text (a bit stark vs otherwise soft neutrals); the footer email uses a default bright blue with default underline that clashes with the muted scheme; the gradient accent color story doesn’t reappear elsewhere, so the palette feels loosely connected.

typography.explanation: Readable, but several craft issues hold it below baseline: 1) Hero sentence is very long and center‑aligned (~90–100ch) in a high‑contrast serif, creating a heavy block with a loose rag. 2) Mixed voices without a clear system: serif hero, sans body, then a large italic/script‑style line ('I look forward to connecting with you!') that feels disconnected from the rest. 3) Casing inconsistency across UI: nav/CTAs in all‑caps while section headers are in Title Case; outline button labels look over‑tracked relative to body. 4) Small white‑on‑black paragraphs in the dark section look tight for the size, reducing comfort. Limitation: link/hover treatment and scale system are not clearly defined across sections.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure reads like a theme with little bespoke tuning: 1) Repeated left‑text/right‑device rows with identical outline 'VIEW CASE' buttons; little variation or point of view. 2) Device stacks (phones + tablets) dominate but the UI inside is tiny/unreadable; several rows mix device types and aspect ratios, causing rhythm flicker. 3) A pale callout band ('I look forward to…') floats center‑aligned and not obviously tied to the grid; later a full‑bleed black content band creates a sharp structural break. 4) Project tiles sit on different light‑grey mats with varied internal spacing, so bottoms/visual weights don’t feel equal across rows. Limitation: no evidence of a disciplined spacing system or optical alignment corrections across sections.

color.explanation: Palette is serviceable: mostly neutral black/white with a soft mint accent repeated in the hero motif and a callout band. Positives: accents are sparse and the mint is restrained. Issues: 1) A sudden full‑black section produces a strong value jump that interrupts flow. 2) Mixed device imagery introduces many saturated hues; without unifying mats/shadows the grid flickers. 3) Whites and light greys differ between device frames and tile backgrounds, adding minor mismatch. Limitation: state colors and a clear accent system beyond the mint aren’t evident.

typography.explanation: Refined, minimal type with disciplined rhythm. Evidence: 1) Comfortable single-column measure (~56–64ch) with ~1.5 leading; rags are clean. 2) Clear two-level hierarchy: project titles in a heavier weight with consistent Title Case; meta lines are lighter/smaller in a muted grey. 3) Micro-craft details: en-dashes used for date ranges (e.g., 2024–25, 2024–present) and centered middle-dot separators consistently spaced. 4) Links appear customized (muted grey, no default blue/underline) and repeat across the nav. Limitation: link discoverability and state styling aren’t visible; very sparse evidence (one view) and the muted nav grey may be low-contrast on some displays.

layout_composition.explanation: Competent, restrained single-column layout. Evidence: 1) Even vertical rhythm between list items (consistent row spacing in the list). 2) Left-aligned column with generous negative space; avatar, name, role, and nav stack with consistent offsets. 3) Repeated item pattern (title + meta) aligns perfectly, giving a steady scan path. Limitation: only a basic list is shown—no complex grid, imagery handling, or multi-section structure to demonstrate higher-level composition; the very light visual affordance for click targets feels under-specified.

color.explanation: Neutral-driven palette is calm and controlled. Evidence: 1) Off-white background with off-black primary text avoids harsh #000/#fff. 2) Meta lines use a consistent mid-grey that supports hierarchy without clashing. 3) No noisy accents; palette stays disciplined and unobtrusive. Limitation: links use a very muted grey that may blend with body/meta and lacks a clearly defined accent role or visible states; limited evidence beyond this single view.

typography.explanation: Type system is minimal and generic: uppercase 'LISA CHEN' lockup paired with very small, lowercase pill links creates a tonal mismatch. Navigation pills use a defaultish sans with light grey text and thin 1px borders; no visible link/hover styling or hierarchy beyond size. There are no heading levels or body copy to demonstrate rhythm or scale, and the footer microcopy is faint and tightly spaced. Positives: text is legible and spacing around the logo/nav is adequate. Limitation: lacks a defined typographic system and customized link treatment.

layout_composition.explanation: Three‑column square tile grid with even gutters keeps basic order, but image handling weakens the composition: (1) mixed device photos (handheld iPhone, Android phone, desktop iMac) alongside flat posters create rhythm flicker; (2) UI content inside devices is too small to read, so tiles act as decorative thumbnails rather than clear work previews; (3) no unifying mats or consistent borders around thumbnails—each tile's background value changes sharply, making the grid feel noisy; (4) top area is a logo plus pill filters with large white space, then a dense grid—section transitions feel abrupt. Red flag applied: sloppy_images (unreadable screenshots, mixed device frames, and lack of unifying mats) → layout capped at 2.

color.explanation: Neutral shell is pure white with a light textured side pattern, but color control is weak in the gallery: saturated tiles (teal, purple, bright yellow/green) sit next to photo‑real device shots without any harmonizing frame, causing value and hue flicker across rows. Pill filters are pale grey, adding another unrelated tone. No clear accent system or tuned neutrals (reads as pure #fff/#000‑ish). Positive: the logo introduces a small accent pairing, but it doesn't carry through the interface. Limitation: needs a unified mat/border or restrained accent palette to control the busy artwork.

typography.explanation:
- All-caps section headings (ABOUT/PORTFOLIO/CONTACT) with wide tracking feel generic and heavy, offering little hierarchy nuance.
- Long center-aligned paragraph in the About section creates a weak rag and a wide measure (~70–90ch), reducing readability.
- Link/label system appears default (nav "Home" pill; no visible custom link style or states), and the small sublabel “design | research | strategy” uses thin separators rather than a clear typographic pattern.
- Minor inconsistencies: heading underline motif vs plain subheads; numbers (01/02/03) don't relate clearly in scale/weight to adjacent labels.
Limitation: Lacks bespoke tuning (no customized underline thickness/offset, state styles, or clear type scale across sections).

layout_composition.explanation:
- Sections are clearly separated, but heavy decorative wave bands above/below create visual noise and interrupt vertical rhythm.
- Portfolio grid is evenly spaced but the tiles mix device photos, illustrations, and real-life shots; several include small, unreadable UI inside laptops/phones, which weakens the gallery’s clarity.
- The “Guiding Principles” row shows three columns where labels wrap to two lines with uneven rags, causing visual misalignment under the centered numerals (01/02/03).
- Contact form fields span different widths and the small purple "Send" button floats without strong grid alignment.
Limitation: Feels theme-driven with little bespoke structure; imagery handling lacks a unifying presentation system.

color.explanation:
- Use of multiple large wave gradients (lavender/teal) introduces competing hues and value bands that distract from content.
- Portfolio tiles bring saturated, mixed-color imagery without neutral mats, creating value/hue flicker across the grid.
- Shell relies on near pure black header strip and white background with minimal tuning; the purple “Send” button adds an unrelated accent.
Limitation: No evident neutral system (soft borders/shadows) to harmonize diverse artwork or control contrast across sections.

typography.explanation: Editorial serif voice in the hero with proper em-dash usage and tasteful italic emphasis; leading appears ~1.4–1.5 and reads comfortably. Small project captions repeat a consistent light‑gray micro style under each tile. Nav text is light and restrained. Limitations: the hero measure is very long (~90–100ch) making the first paragraph heavy to read; caption text is quite small/low-contrast; no visible link styling or state system to judge consistency.

layout_composition.explanation: Two‑column masonry layout with clear page margins; vertical/horizontal gutters look mostly even; captions sit at a consistent offset beneath images. Imagery is presented cleanly without device frames and crops look intentional. Limitations: several tiles don’t fill their column width (e.g., the small 'twitch' tile floating in a wide right column), creating awkward voids; bottoms of items in a row don’t align which breaks vertical rhythm; the very large black panel dominates the flow and adds weight imbalance.

color.explanation: Neutral shell (light background, near‑black type) lets project imagery carry color. No default bright link blue visible; overall harmony is acceptable. Limitations: strong value swings across tiles (deep black panel next to bright yellow and saturated purple) create flicker because there are no mats/borders to unify diverse artwork; caption gray is on the faint side, reducing readability.

typography.explanation: Readable, organized type with a clear hierarchy but not notably bespoke. Observations: 1) Project titles are set in a heavier weight with consistent Title Case, paired with small all‑caps meta (e.g., WEB/MOBILE) that repeats across items. 2) Body measures are comfortable (roughly 55–75ch) with stable leading; hero paragraph is left‑aligned and easy to scan. 3) Links use a bright cobalt blue consistently throughout. Limitations: the link styling feels defaultish (no visible custom underline/hover); casing mixes all‑lowercase in the hero/nav with Title Case headings, which weakens system cohesion; decorative emoji in hero/footer adds a casual tone that slightly reduces polish.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is disciplined and repeats well across sections. Observations: 1) Case‑study rows use a consistent pattern (image left, text right) with matching aspect‑ratio thumbnails and uniform corner radii; gutters and image/text offsets look even. 2) The 'Additional Work' section maintains two equal columns with regular vertical rhythm; captions and VIEW CTAs align to the same grid. 3) Section labels ('CASE STUDIES', 'ADDITIONAL WORK') provide clear section breaks without width drift—containers feel consistent from hero through grid. Limitation: the very bold full‑width blue footer breaks the otherwise calm rhythm, and some tile heights in the two‑column area differ slightly, introducing minor vertical rhythm flicker.

color.explanation: Palette is serviceable with a single strong accent and calm neutrals. Observations: 1) Bright cobalt is used consistently for links and as the dominant footer color. 2) Thumbnail mats employ soft pastels (light blue, peach) plus a dark navy, generally controlled in value so text remains primary. 3) Neutral shell (white background, dark text, grey meta) supports readability. Limitation: the accent blue is very saturated and the solid blue footer creates a sharp value jump; mixed mat hues across tiles aren’t fully harmonized, causing mild color flicker.

typography.explanation: Readable, conservative sans with clear hierarchy but generic execution. Evidence: 1) Centered hero sentence set at a comfortable single‑line measure; 2) Project titles in Title Case with spaced sublabels in all‑caps (e.g., 'PRODUCT DESIGN / VISUAL DESIGN'); 3) Outline CTAs use uppercase consistently. Issues/limitations: default‑ish voice with little bespoke tuning, link/CTA styling feels boilerplate, and minor inconsistency where the first tile says 'VIEW MY WORK' while the rest say 'VIEW PROJECT'. Template scent present (centered 'I’m [Name]' hero + uniform outline buttons), so Typography is capped at 3.

layout_composition.explanation: Simple two‑column rows with even horizontal rules provide basic structure, but imagery handling drags the quality down. Evidence: 1) Reliance on generic device renders (laptops/iMacs/iPhones) with tiny, unreadable UI; 2) Mixed device types and aspect ratios per row create rhythm flicker—tile heights vary noticeably (e.g., tall iPhone stack vs wider iMac); 3) Internal mats and bezels differ per device, so the visual weight of each row is inconsistent; 4) CTAs sit identically inside each row but do not align to a visible grid beyond the center line, yielding a template‑module feel. Red flag applied: sloppy_images (mixed devices + unreadable screenshots + inconsistent mats), so Layout is capped at 2.

color.explanation: Chrome is mostly grayscale with light dividers and outline buttons, but the page lacks unifying tactics to harmonize varied artwork. Evidence: 1) Strong color spikes from screenshots (e.g., bright orange, teal) against a plain white shell cause value/hue flicker between rows; 2) Different device bezels and internal whites don’t match the page white, increasing contrast jitter; 3) No visible hover/active color system for links/CTAs, keeping the palette flat and default‑leaning. Limitation: neutral tuning is minimal and doesn’t tame the diverse imagery.

typography.explanation: Distinct serif display for the hero paired with a clean sans for body/nav creates a clear hierarchy. Upper‑nav and section labels use spaced all‑caps consistently; hero title has tight but non‑colliding leading and balanced word breaks. Link styling is customized (teal color with underlines) and repeats across lists. Body copy in the three columns has comfortable leading and tidy bullets/rags. Limitation: the body text size is on the small side for desktop, and the centered intro paragraph feels slightly detached from the column system.

layout_composition.explanation: A disciplined three‑column grid under the hero with equal square illustration tiles, matched mats, and even gutters. Section labels, paragraphs, and bullet lists align cleanly under each tile, maintaining vertical rhythm. The top bar and hero establish a straightforward scan path. Limitations: only a single view is visible, and the centered outline CTA ('See my work') floats without anchoring to the three‑column grid, creating a minor break in structure; the centered intro block above the columns introduces a small alignment shift.

color.explanation: Cohesive palette: a single teal accent used for nameplate, links, nav, and button; off‑black text on off‑white background; beige illustration mats unify the three tiles and control value. Color roles are clear and consistent with no clashing elements, and value contrast remains calm across the page. Limitation: the teal accent reads slightly hot against the otherwise muted neutrals, and state colors (hover/visited) aren’t demonstrated.

typography.explanation: Readable, restrained system but fairly default. Observations: 1) Body intro set to a comfortable ~60–70ch with ~1.4–1.6 leading, easy to scan. 2) Project titles show consistent size/weight and Title Case; the smaller source label (e.g., 'Amplitude') repeats with the same tone/placement. 3) Micro‑labels in the hero (social icons in small bordered squares) and the footer repeat consistently. Limitations: default‑ish geometric sans with little custom link styling; casing drifts between all‑caps nav ('WORK / ABOUT ME') and Title Case elsewhere; icon buttons show slight weight/size mismatch (LinkedIn vs other icon) and the email CTA’s thin outline feels light compared with surrounding type.

layout_composition.explanation: Clear grid and consistent project rows. Observations: 1) Repeated two‑column tiles with left‑aligned text block and right image maintain equal left margins and predictable vertical rhythm. 2) Image treatments (screens or device frames) sit on large color panels with consistent internal paddings; right‑edge crops feel intentional and repeat. 3) Section break 'Open to chat!' uses the same container width and keeps alignment disciplined. Limitations: overall structure reads template‑like (centered hero followed by identical two‑column rows); screenshot content on some tiles is small and not highly readable; center‑aligned hero to left‑aligned work section shift lacks an explicit transitional device.

color.explanation: Color is lively and mostly controlled. Observations: 1) Each project panel uses a cohesive, single dominant field color (aqua, lavender, light gray, yellow) that cleanly contains varied artwork. 2) Cool blues recur across the first two tiles, giving some continuity; neutrals elsewhere (white page background, pale gray contact band) are comfortable and not pure #000/#fff harsh. 3) Contrast within panels is adequate (dark text on light fields). Limitations: panel‑to‑panel value jumps cause some page‑level flicker—especially the bright yellow tile against cooler neighbors; social icon colors introduce minor noise; no visible, unified link/CTA color system beyond the single outline button.

typography.explanation: Minimal, text‑forward page shows disciplined type: approximately 60–70ch measure with ~1.5 leading; consistent sentence‑case headings like “Building / Projects / Writing” used as micro‑labels; body rags are even with no obvious widows/orphans. Links are customized (↗ indicators, no default blue) and appear consistently across the lists. Emphasis via italic phrases is sparing and readable; punctuation such as em dashes and commas is handled consistently. Limitation: link states aren’t clearly visible and some small meta text appears slightly light, which could reduce discoverability.

layout_composition.explanation: Clear, restrained grid: a left‑aligned single column for intro and narrative, followed by a tidy three‑column row with equal column widths and consistent gutters; vertical rhythm between sections (“Now,” “Connect”) is even and likely on a spacing system. Content blocks align to a single left edge producing a clean scan. Negative space is used deliberately, and list items maintain uniform offsets. Limitation: evidence is limited to a single, simple page with low structural complexity; the narrow column may feel small on large screens.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals throughout: off‑white canvas with off‑black text and softer grey for meta copy; values are controlled, yielding calm contrast without harsh #000/#fff. The monochrome approach keeps focus on content and feels cohesive. No clashing accents or noisy tiles. Limitation: almost no accent color or visible interactive states; the light grey used for small labels skirts low contrast.

typography.explanation: Readable sans used with adequate contrast; body intro and card copy are legible. However, casing and scale vary: hero uses sentence case while the nameplate is all‑caps and a later 'OTHER PROJECTS' billboard is oversized all‑caps; project titles are Title Case, and a giant 'TOPHATTER' wordmark dominates a card. Hierarchy relies on inconsistent size jumps and thin rules; link treatment/states are not evident. Overall competent but generic with visible inconsistencies.

layout_composition.explanation: Large card grid provides structure, but execution is uneven. Mixed card mats and internal paddings (e.g., right top card has a thick dark bottom bar while the left one doesn’t). A device mock on the Tophatter tile sits tight to the edge while other cards keep wider margins, breaking rhythm. Billboard 'OTHER PROJECTS' text is cropped by the tile edges. Sloppy imagery cues: generic phone frame with tiny, unreadable UI; multiple screenshots too small to evaluate (GoodHire, CEGA); mixed asset styles (photos, logos, device frames) without harmonized presentation. These issues disrupt alignment and vertical rhythm.

color.explanation: Pastel backgrounds shift per card (cool blue, peach, light cyan, tan), causing hue/value flicker across the grid. Saturated brand colors (e.g., purple wordmark, multicolor footer social icons) add noise rather than act as controlled accents. There’s no evident unifying mat/border tint to harmonize varied imagery, so the page reads visually busy.

typography.explanation: Readable, modern sans with clear hierarchy, but largely default. Evidence: 1) Headline casing drifts — “Stunning Designs” (Title Case) vs “Thoughtful experiences” (sentence case) and later “Got a Project? Let’s talk.” with mixed capitalization; 2) Comfortable body measure and leading in hero (~60–70ch, ~1.4–1.6 leading); 3) Link pattern repeats (“Case Study →”, “Contact Us →”) with consistent arrow treatment; 4) Heavy display weight used repeatedly, creating blocky, same‑voice headings. Limitation: generic Inter‑like system with limited typographic voice and inconsistent casing. Red‑flag cap applied: template_scent_high limits Typography to 3.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure follows a standard landing‑page stack (centered hero → logo band → testimonials → project tiles → CTA → contact) with adequate spacing, but image handling and rhythm reduce polish. Evidence: 1) Project tiles use mixed aspect ratios and heights (text card next to an iPad mock; large green panel with a laptop) causing rhythm flicker; 2) Reliance on generic device frames (laptop/tablet/multiple phones) with tiny, unreadable UI; 3) The large green block behind the laptop disrupts vertical/value rhythm and feels disconnected from the grid; 4) Case‑study links float at different positions (e.g., top‑right on green tile) rather than a unified caption system. Limitation: lacks a cohesive POV and precise grid discipline. Red flags: sloppy_images (unreadable screenshots, mixed device frames, inconsistent tile sizes) → cap Layout at 2; template_scent_high (hero/logo band/testimonial modules) noted.

color.explanation: Base neutrals are pleasant (soft grey sections, dark navy text), but accent strategy is noisy. Evidence: 1) Competing accents — bright teal/green panel, cobalt‑blue links, and black pill CTAs; 2) The saturated green case‑study panel spikes value and overpowers nearby content; 3) Device screenshots introduce many additional hues without unifying mats/borders, increasing visual noise; 4) Project card backgrounds vary (green block, pale gradient, white), leading to value flicker across the grid. Limitation: needs a tighter accent system and unified mats to harmonize diverse imagery.

typography.explanation: Clear, restrained system. Hero block uses a clean sans with measured scale (bold name, light body) and an even ~55–65ch measure with ~1.5 leading. Custom link styling on “Turf” (thin underline, offset below baseline) and a tasteful red superscript asterisk/footnote show micro‑craft. Meta labels like “NOTION” use consistent all‑caps with balanced tracking. Rags are stable; no widows/orphans apparent. Limitations: embedded tweet brings a conflicting font/voice; casing varies across areas (lowercase body vs Title Case nav) which slightly dilutes cohesion; interactive link states beyond the hero aren’t demonstrated.

layout_composition.explanation: Cohesive 4‑column masonry grid with consistent gutters and identical rounded tile radii; tiles share the same soft mats and subtle shadows, unifying diverse content. Intro text tile anchors the page and establishes hierarchy; repeated bottom‑left circular chevron affordances are positioned consistently. Screenshots and device frames are contained within cards with adequate padding; no cut‑offs. Limitations: masonry produces ragged row bottoms; one rotated phone tile adds slight rhythm disruption; several screenshots are too small to read, reducing proof of detail.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals (off‑white canvas, soft grey card mats, off‑black text) create a calm shell. Accent red is used sparingly (nav dot, asterisk, a few cards) and balances well with occasional warm gradients; imagery color is contained by neutral mats so the grid doesn’t flicker. Shadows are light and hue‑controlled. Limitations: the Twitter embed’s saturated blue and a few hot red gradient tiles spike value slightly; subtle differences in grey mat values create minor variation across tiles.

typography.explanation: Minimal, disciplined sans system with clear hierarchy across three columns. Observations: 1) Comfortable measures (~60–70ch) and even ~1.4–1.6 leading in the middle column; rags are tidy with no widows. 2) Headings ('Projects', 'Thoughts & ideas') use a consistent weight/size step above item titles; dates/meta set smaller in a lighter grey for a stable scale. 3) Links are customized (no default blue; arrow glyph '→' consistently appended) and read as a coherent pattern. 4) Baselines within each column feel aligned; list indents and spacing are consistent. Limitations: slight casing/voice mismatch between sentence‑case hero ('Hello, I'm Rasmus') and Title‑style section labels; right‑column nav text appears quite light, flirting with low contrast; states (hover/visited) aren’t shown. Minimalism Micro‑Craft signals are strong enough to justify 4 on a single view.

layout_composition.explanation: Crisp three‑column grid with disciplined spacing. Observations: 1) Columns share a common top line and consistent column widths; gutters are even. 2) Repeated list items in left and middle columns maintain identical mats and vertical rhythm; 'Browse all…' rows align to the grid. 3) Right column groups bio, vertical nav, and two cards with matching radii/padding, keeping composition cohesive. 4) Dark side gutters frame the content area and keep focus centered. Limitations: the orange dot + vertical nav feels slightly floaty relative to the main column grid, and the heavy side gutters create strong value edges; only one breakpoint/view is visible so broader consistency can’t be verified.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals with a single accent produce calm hierarchy.
